Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2014 11:39AM bella1965 wrote: Thank you sooo much 4inthefamily....your supportive words help more than you know :)  My mom and I are very spiritual and rely heavily on our faith so you are so very right in your advice to expect the worst but pray for the best.  That is exactly what I have been doing and what is keeping my head above water right now.  The fear of the unknown is what is killing me.  I go back and forth between having these wonderfully positive thoughts to all of a sudden sinking into deep despair and thinking the worst.  The battle that is raging in my head is steady but I am fighting it every step of the way and refusing to let the blackness seep through.  I suspect that once Mom has had her biopsies and we know exactly what we are dealing with I will regain that old fighting spirit but right now it is so hard to deal with it all because we are in limbo until a diagnosis is made.  Mom very recently underwent surgery for a back problem and so she was unable to have her biopsies when they were originally slated to be performed.  She has to wait three weeks now in order to have healed enough to lay on the table for 90 minutes while they are conducted.  However I have been assured by the doctors that three weeks is not going to harm her in any way so that at least is a comfort.  In any event, the waiting is truly the hardest part but we will get through and your words of encouragement in a so very similar situation give me strength :)  Thanks so much for the support-it is appreciated more than you know :)

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2014 01:52PM bella1965 wrote: Thank you so much April for your kind and supportive words   I am so thankful to have such a wonderful group of people here to vent to and to receive advice and support from.  I know that once we get a diagnosis things will start to become more clear and if in fact this turns out to be cancer, once Mom receives a treatment plan we can start to see our way through all of this   I am definitely going to stay positive and strong for Mom, as hard as I know it will be because she is more worried about me than she is herself which breaks my heart.  That is my Mom....always worried about someone else and never herself.  I am just so very thankful that she is so incredibly strong spiritually and physically and positive in outlook because I know that will serve her well as we potentially go down this road together   Thank you again so much for your kindness and once the results are in on September 23rd I will definitely be in touch and let you know how things went.  In the meantime, have a great day and hugs right back to you

Posts.Content: bella1965 wrote: Hi everyone, I am new to the site :)  My mom discovered a lump in her breast July 3rd but only told me a week later because she didn't want me to worry :(  After going through the process we are now at the stage where she has been diagnosed as Birads 5 and is waiting for her biopsies.  The mammo and ultrasound found two lumps, both 2 cm and smaller in her right breast with cortical thickening of the axilla.  My mom is doing absolutely fabulous....she is 77 years young and is one of the most positive people I have ever known.  She is taking all of this in her stride and is ready to tackle whatever challenges may come her way.  I, however, feel like I am losing my mind.  I am an only child and my Mom lives with my husband and I.  She and I are incredibly close and the thought of losing her or even watching her go through this whole agonizing process is driving me to the edge with worry.  I had a very close brush with breast cancer myself five years ago right before my wedding.  At the time, the doctors told me that based on what they were seeing on the mammogram my chances of having breast cancer were between 80-90%.  I had no lump....just what appeared to be distortion on the mammo.  Long story short, it turned out to be nothing more than fibroglandular tissue but the nightmare that I went through waiting for results and going through the whole process was agonizing.  Now, five years later, I find myself in the same position with my Mom and I am not sure how to get through this.  If only lumps were found I think I could handle it better but the fact that they are seeing thickening in the axilla and enlarged nodes is terrifying for me.  I know that no one but a pathologist can tell you for sure whether you have breast cancer but I guess I am looking for some ray of hope that even if Mom is diagnosed and there is spread to the nodes and beyond that treatment is available for her that would enable her to live a happy life.  Any inspiration or information would be most helpful :)  Thanks so much....
